Some projects have used a different approach. They manage test s=
uites manually. What you have called "BagTest" would be "BagSuite" for them=
, and in BagSuite you would find a hand-built test suite that refers to all=
 the classes that contain tests for a Bag. BagSuite would refer to EmptyBag=
Test, HelloTwiceBagTest and OneItemBagTest, for example. This way you know =
immediately to look at BagSuite to find all the bag tests.

When you open i=
t, though, BagSuite does nothing more than say "see EmptyBagTest, HelloTwic=
eBagTest and OneItemBagTest for details." I claim that seeing the three Jav=
a source files all named *BagTest.java does the same work without the extra=
 source file.

As for a well-defined starting point, the set of test files =
*BagTest.java *is* a well-defined, obviously-named starting point. It is pe=
rhaps slightly less obvious than opening "BagTest.java", but not so much th=
at it poses a problem. If someone wants to write "BagTest.java", then that'=
s cool with me, but I wouldn't do it.

 things about

It does. Another technique is talk=
ing to people: a close-knit team will agree to standards and uphold them, o=
bviating the need for documentation masquerading as code. Another technique=
 is a drawing on the wall, or a list on the corkboard.

I have a general av=
ersion to code that does nothing more than document something. That's why w=
e have documentation. Code should be self-documenting, but it should also d=
o something useful at runtime.

And keep in mind: we'll all teachers and st=
udents here.

Take care.
